details.excerpt: Last week was 20% week. I spent a bit of time setting up and playing with the remarkable [dokku](http://progrium.com/blog/2013/06/19/dokku-the-smallest-paas-implementation-youve-ever-seen/), which may prove useful for some of our upcoming projects. I also managed to wrap my head around some of the new features in [cucumber-chef 3](https://github.com/Atalanta/cucumber-chef), to which I'll be moving our infrastructure-testing stuff in due course.
details.content:
Last week was 20% week. I spent a bit of time setting up and playing with the remarkable dokku, which may prove useful for some of our upcoming projects. I also managed to wrap my head around some of the new features in cucumber-chef 3, to which I'll be moving our infrastructure-testing stuff in due course.

James and I delivered the Friday Lunchtime Lecture, which required a bit of preparation (including Jekyll-ising the reveal.js presentation), but most of James's week was taken up with working out how to usefully diff CSVs with Git, as well as getting himself booked in for OKCon in September.

Ulrich spent a couple of days training statisticians in Edinburgh, but then his main focus was on the peer-to-peer lending data, which made it to the front page of today's Financial Times!

Tom was occupied with building research relationships with new people at a couple of institutions, namely Edinburgh and QMUL, as well as continuing to pursue the FP7 funding.

Stuart's 20% time was taken up with some initial investigations into how many addresses are listed within available open data; he also built most of the peer-to-peer site.

Jeni worked on how to embed open data into procurement policy, and discussed and supported the use of Open Data Certificates in a variety of organisations large and small.

However, the main thing we have learned this week is that the national animal of Scotland is the unicorn.
